conclusion: Understanding the problem involves a graph of volume versus temperature for an ideal gas with points A, B, and C.
Point A is at (T₀, V₀), point B is at (T₀, 2V₀), and point C is on the line connecting A and B.
Line segment AB is parallel to the V-axis, indicating constant temperature from A to B.
Pressure at point A is p₀, and work done from A to B is 10 J.
Recalling the ideal gas law: pV = nRT.
First law of thermodynamics: ΔU = Q - W.
From A to B, temperature is constant, indicating an isothermal process.
For an isothermal process, work done is W = nRT ln(V_f / V_i).
Given V_f = 2V₀ and V_i = V₀, W = nRT₀ ln(2).
Using pV = constant for isothermal process, p_B = p₀ / 2.
For isothermal process, ΔU = 0, so Q = W.
